The Supine Spinal Twist works core muscles (obliques, lower back), glutes, hips, and shoulders while stretching the spine, chest, and hamstrings, improving spinal mobility through a gentle rotation (thoracic and lumbar) and hip release, making it great for tension relief, digestion, and cool-downs. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked (Stretched & Engaged) 

• Primary: Obliques (side abs), Lower Back (Quadratus Lumborum - QL). 
• Secondary: Glutes (especially Piriformis), Hips, Shoulders, Chest, Hamstrings, Abdominal muscles (toned). [1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 8]  

Movement Patterns 

• Spinal Rotation (Torso): The primary movement is a gentle twist or rotation of the thoracic (upper) and lumbar (lower) spine. 
• Hip External Rotation: The hips rotate as the knees drop to one side. 
• Core Stabilization: The core muscles (obliques, transverse abdominis) engage to control the movement and keep the upper body stable. 
• Shoulder Stabilization & Chest Opening: The arms extend, stretching the shoulders and opening the chest. 
• Gentle Lengthening: Deep stretches occur in the glutes, hips, QL, and hamstrings. [2, 3, 4, 7, 8, 9, 10]  

Key Benefits 

• Releases tension in the back, hips, and shoulders. 
• Improves spinal mobility and flexibility. 
• Massages abdominal organs, aiding digestion. 
• Aids in relaxation and stress relief. [2, 4, 7, 11]  

How to Perform (Basic Movement) 

1. Lie on your back (supine). 
2. Hug knees to chest or extend arms out to the sides (T-shape). 
3. Slowly drop bent knees to one side, keeping shoulders grounded. 
4. Turn your head away from the knees (optional). 
5. Hold, breathing deeply, then switch sides. [3, 4, 12]
